üìöI put my Learning and Development budget to work in the last few days on 2025 to pick up some new and some all time favourite books for my collection. üìö

This is a pretty clear indication of what I‚Äôm into reading about, any recommendations for my newly renewed budget? ü§ë

üéÅ My Commercial Enablement 2025 Wrapped üéÅ 

You know me, I love to reflect on and recognize the impact I've made. Creating a positive impact on the teams I support drives me everyday to do my best work. Any enablement folks that follow me, I'd love to see your wrapped too! 

‚öíÔ∏è Top enablement tool: 
It can at times be difficult to prove your impact in enablement, but with Gong as my enablement sidekick it's never been easier to get the visibility I need to prove impact. I used it 227 days out of the working year. 

üèÜ Top 3 Initiatives: 
1. I designed and delivered a commercial-wide upskilling program to help our teams have more impactful conversations with our clients. We saw a 120% increase in better questions asked and a 105% increase in next steps set. 

2. Increased Gong usage across the team. I used a simple "generate awareness" approach to Gong this year. I made the team aware of new features and use cases through my other programs, slack updates and targeted convos when needed. Daily usage is up 46% across the team! 

3. I've managed all call scorecards for our team to ensure there is a through-line from training to call feedback. In Q4, I started on a call autoscoring strategy to create call feedback at scale and improve visibility into skills gaps we can close. 

‚åö Total hours spent on face to face training (in-person or virtual): 67
I believe face to face, practice and application based training that includes coaching and feedback is the most valuable use of my time. 

My team has big plans to kick-off in 2026 after a brief pause to relax and recharge with friends and family over the holidays üéÑ

üö® Serious question for the folks using lots of AI day in and day out.... üö® 

What are you doing while you wait for the LLM to do its magic? 

Before I'd be locked in on deep focused work. Now, I cue up the AI and let it run. I can't fully move on because the output is important for my next step but I can't just wait because I get distracted and waste time. 

How do you maximize time in this new way of working? Share your best practices below.

Today we announced an equity round of up to $750 million at a $10 billion post-money valuation. The round was co-led by Dragoneer and GIC, and includes a group of world-renowned new and returning investors.

We chose this group of investors because of their proven track record scaling category leaders, and because they are committed to the long-term future of Wealthsimple. They believe in our vision for the future of financial services.

This funding will supercharge our growth by helping us scale our products and deliver more value to our clients.

More from our CEO and co-founder Michael Katchen below.

https://lnkd.in/gsREmiDg

Spending the last few days at Gong Celebrate was energizing, inspiring and has me so pumped to keep building out automated scorecards for my team üòÖ 

Three huge takeaways from the fast evolving world of revenue intelligence: 

1Ô∏è‚É£ Solving for manual entry: A future where we can say, "Back in my day, we had to actually type words to fill in CRM fields, manually, one field and one opportunity at a time" is literally in our grasp, and every sales organization is trying to solve the problem of manual entry so that their data foundation is rock solid. 

2Ô∏è‚É£ Creating an Interoperable AI Future: Hearing leaders from Salesforce, Microsoft and Gong say that they are moving away from viewing each other as competitors to recognizing each other as partners in data. Huge SaaS giants saying let's recognize each other's strengths so that we can build a smarter, faster agentic future together was a big moment I don't think I'll easily forget. 

3Ô∏è‚É£ Reimagining processes for AI: It's tempting to jump in and throw AI at everything - but that's why most AI pilots fail. To build with AI successfully, you have to be brave enough to tear it all down and build it back up by identifying the right tasks for AI to own that compliment human ability. 

On the personal side, hearing from many other leaders about their adoption of Gong and AI made me so proud of the work I've done at Wealthsimple. 

Two key tactics for anyone early in their Gong implementation: 

‚û°Ô∏è Don't wait to be told what to share, just start sharing insights. Did someone  mention something in a meeting that they "think" is behind a change in metrics? Use Gong to validate and share out what you learned. 

‚û°Ô∏è I heard a lot about trouble with scorecard adoption and that is a tough one to crack! And the old saying applies - you have to measure it to make it matter. Set a target for call reviews for each leader. Start with # of comments/month, then build out scorecards and set a target for scorecards completed/month. Share out monthly metrics to hold everyone accountable. 

We are living in revolutionary times. I hope I'll be back next year to see how the world of revenue intelligence has evolved.

Wealthsimple wants every Canadian to achieve financial freedom and for one lucky Canadian that means we're giving them a house üè† and $100k. 

This contest is another example of why I love working at Wealthsimple. The creativity and willingness to bring big ideas to life quickly is unmatched. 

So enter below! Share with your friends and family and I hope one of my followers becomes a homeowner through this contest üòÜ 

https://lnkd.in/gFhvmp-t

ü§ñ How I used AI as my enablement co-pilot to design 5 engaging, interactive in-person training sessions for my team (in less than 2 weeks) ü§ñ  

This week, Wealthsimple hosted the entire Commercial team in Toronto. I've learned so much from how we approached enablement during the last 2 takeovers I was a part of and so I knew this time, I wanted to do more sessions so that each team had the opportunity to learn and practice together. 

More sessions, mean more content, and I only gave myself 9 business days to get it all done üôÉ. So that meant I needed to find more ways to use AI to help me, so how did we divide and conquer to bring everything to life?

I engaged with stakeholders to shape the content, collected internal documentation and created the decks (not ready to give that up yet üôà - but in a pinch, I love Gamma). Google Gemini was my creative assistant coming up with snappy acronyms, fun names for specific talk tracks and of course, my Kim-style presentation Gem writes my slide notes. 
 
I used my Gong search superpowers to find relevant call snippets for exercises, but since recorded call audio isn't always high quality or fun to listen to, Descript brought the words real clients say to life with realistic AI voice and video with 1-click captions for easy comprehension. 

I decided that the team will practice through rapid fire exercises, Google Gemini came up tons of realistic variations of client pain statements and objections to use so that each team had more than enough examples to work with. Anyone who has had to come up with realistic examples in the past, knows how game changing this is. 

And just like that the week is over, everything delivered seamlessly and I'm sitting here thinking, what's next for me and my enablement co-pilots üë©‚Äç‚úàÔ∏è üë©‚Äç‚úàÔ∏è ?

I can‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs already been one year with Wealthsimple ü§Ø

One year in and I feel so lucky to work at Wealthsimple. 

When I was looking to make a switch, I knew I wanted to work for a values-driven organization. 

The last year has proved to me that Wealthsimple is driven by the values. Over the last year they‚Äôve shaped my experience and solidified how much I love working at Wealthsimple. Let‚Äôs break it down‚Ä¶

üë©üèº‚Äçüç≥Maker-owner: I‚Äôve been able to own the design and delivery of a commercial team wide sales skill training program that is changing how our team engages with clients. Hearing team members ask better, more curious questions on calls will never get old. 

üí≥The client, the client, the client: Seeing how each feature rollout is guided by improving the client experience is a constant push to keep the client at the centre of enablement as well. Our clients are ready for change in the industry and Wealthsimple delivers. 

üöÄShip-it: I‚Äôve been able to ship projects spanning the scope of what I dreamed an enablement role would be. From facilitating in-person training at our team takeovers to virtual sessions on handling objections, small team coaching sessions, creating elearning and tackling the  challenge of tracking adoption at scale of many many things üòÖ. I have shipped so many more things than I would have imagined in 1-year. 

üôåüèª Naive ambition: As someone who often thinks too big for what I am actually able to accomplish as one person, I love this value most. It helps me take my dream, believe, achieve mindset into my day to day. If I believe a bet is important, it‚Äôs often worth finding out if it‚Äôs true. Though it may seem like a small thing, the push this value gives me to share thoughts and insights not as a final product but as a piece of moving the big picture forward is a huge motivator day to day. 

üëÜüèªKeep it simple: The hardest one for me (see I love naive ambition above). The perfect check to remind me that a big idea can also be simplified many times over for similar impact. Many times I‚Äôve been asked, ‚ÄúCould you simplify?‚Äù Sometimes that can be taken negatively but at Wealthsimple, it‚Äôs a nudge in the right direction. 

‚ù§Ô∏èBe human: The people at Wealthsimple are very kind humans. Building many incredible things fast and maintaining a person-first culture is not easy. There is always room to make space for what each person needs to be successful and encourage them to work in the way that is best for them. The remote-work flexibility, benefits, and culture make it easy to do my best work. 

Here‚Äôs to an amazing first year of what I hope will be a loooooong relationship ü•∞

data.text: Come join my team!

When I started at Wealthsimple, I never imagined that within the first 6 months I‚Äôd be recognized for my impact on the team. ü§Ø

Last week, I won the Rita Choi award at the Commercial team President‚Äôs Awards for my impact on the Sales Strategy and Operations team. ü•π

I could say more, but I feel like Kelly-Marie M.‚Äôs feedback below captures it all. I‚Äôm so grateful to work with everyone on the Commercial team. I can‚Äôt wait to look back at everything we achieve together in 2025. üöÄ

ü§ßDoes your team suffer from the common sales cold? ü§ß 

That was the topic of the training I designed and delivered for our 2025 Takeoff last week. 

There are two common symptoms: 

ü•¥ Sales sickness - when you‚Äôve spent too much time thinking about your numbers you lose the ability to hear client‚Äôs needs 

üëÇüèªHappy ears - developing a reflexive response to the first thing a client says that you know you can help with 

If the common sales cold is going around your team, implementing a listening regime is the cure! 

üè•Slow down, ask more and better questions, and build the mental muscle required to not jump into the conversation and respond too soon! 

To build immunity, I prescribed practicing on every client call. 

Have you spotted these symptoms on your team? What‚Äôs your prescription to ward off symptoms? Leave it in the thread below! üëáüèª

An interesting thing happened during the recent postal strike: some financial institutions reduced the volume of account transfers they made by cheque, and made more transfers electronically.

Prior to the strike, you‚Äôd be forgiven for thinking the persistence of cheque transfers was due to a failure or inability to invest in readily available and affordable transfers technology. The blip in electronic transfers when our mail wasn‚Äôt moving suggests something more concerning.

Rob Carrick at The Globe and Mail nails it: "Using the technology of previous centuries says a lot about a company‚Äôs respect for investors and their right to access their own money."

Some of Canada‚Äôs biggest financial institutions do not, or rarely, use this century‚Äôs technology, and it‚Äôs costing investors. Markets rose more than 5% since the end of October. But you don‚Äôt benefit from those gains if your money is stuck in the mail. 

It‚Äôs time for our laws to prohibit this neglect of investors. Some regulators have tried to get their arms around this, CIRO / OCRI foremost among them. But CIRO can‚Äôt go it alone. Our securities, insurance, pension and banking regulators, and the governments they are accountable to, have not made this a priority. That must change. 

If you‚Äôre affected by a delayed transfer, you have the right to complain to OBSI - Ombudsman for Banking Services and Investments, which may recommend compensation from your old institution. But complaining is only a short term solution; it‚Äôs long past time for the financial industry to work together to make cheques and faxes by mail a relic of the last century.

article.title: Investors lost millions of potential gains in the postal strike, and it‚Äôs not just Canada Post‚Äôs fault
article.subtitle: theglobeandmail.com

companyMentions.name: OBSI - Ombudsman for Banking Services and Investments

üîìAnother skill unlocked: live training facilitation! 

üëèüèªDay 1 of our Wealthsimple Commercial team takeover was yesterday and I had the pleasure of kicking off the week with a session on ‚Äúthe facts and feelings of discovery‚Äù. 

üí™üèºBeing in enablement, it‚Äôs been a goal of mine for a while to begin flexing my facilitation muscles. The session went super well and I couldn‚Äôt be happier with the feedback (including how many people were surprised by the dry humour I brought to the presentation). I shamelessly love being told I‚Äôm funny üòÇ

üìöI love to celebrate success and focused on continual learning here. My most important takeaway from the session for me to continue to focus on in facilitation is this:

‚ú®It‚Äôs easy to teach things and convey information. As a facilitator, the most challenging and valuable role is to help people try on what you‚Äôre teaching right away, in the room, then celebrate, support or coach them depending on how it goes. That‚Äôs where learning really starts to stick!

Why do you do lots of research for large purchases like a car or an ongoing service, but when it comes to financial advice you probably have ended up with the first person you met or were referred to.
¬†
This is especially interesting since working with a financial advisor could be the most important service relationship you have in your life.

If you are one of these people, and want to look at alternative options, we have something new for you.

data.text:
As a child of immigrant parents, I was often relied on to support my parent's finances, which was and still is incredibly intimidating! I always felt like this was a lot to take on, but as I became more knowledgeable in the space, I realized there was no need for things to be so overly complicated. 

Wealthsimple's mission to help everyone achieve financial freedom resonated with me, and I want to be part of the journey to break down those barriers and make finances simple and accessible for everyone‚Äîespecially my parents!

Using tech to make finances transparent and low-cost, Wealthsimple has driven over¬†$40B in assets under administration, with the BDR team continuing to drive strong growth in net deposits¬†üìà.  We plan to¬†increase our momentum¬†in 2025, so I'm excited to share some key hires below to support this goal
 so I'm excited to share some key hires below to support this goal!

üëâ Business Development Representative (https://lnkd.in/gbW76bAD)

üëâ Team Lead, Business Development Representative (https://lnkd.in/gex-fTMw)

üëâ Manager, Business Development Representative 
(https://lnkd.in/gbW76bAD)

Today I‚Äôm excited to share that I‚Äôm starting my next role as a Sales Enablement Manager at Wealthsimple. I‚Äôm looking forward to the opportunity to apply everything I know at a company I‚Äôve personally trusted with my investments for years and to continue learning and growing with them in this next chapter.

Today is the end of an era. The last day of my Fusion Learning > DoubleDigit Sales > Richardson Sales Performance journey (one name change and an acquisition later). After a decade, I'm moving on to a really exciting new opportunity (more to come on that later). 

I will never forget back in 2014 being cold called by a recruiter while hanging out in my mom's backyard. She asked me if I liked working on PowerPoint presentations. With a little bit of experience using PowerPoint under my belt and the willingness to do whatever job would pay me, I said, "of course I do." I could have never imagined the door that was about to open. 

You don't learn about the Learning and Development industry in University. No one told me that my Psychology degree was practical because I learned how to understand people. I had no idea that companies in every industry hire other companies to train their people to sell better, to be coaches, to be better managers. I had no idea my job formatting PPT decks would lead me to where I am now. All these years later, I could not be more grateful to have found myself in the sales training, performance improvement and coaching space. I've learned so much. 

I am so grateful to all of the wonderful, supportive people I've worked with in the last 10 years. Every single person has made me better in some way. Thank you. 

I've talked a lot in previous posts about celebrating accomplishments, so I also have to say I'm so proud of myself for getting to where I am going. I can't wait to see what comes next! 

Pictured: Me and my mom in 2014 after I accepted the job at Fusion.

I've been asked a lot recently, what is the most important lesson you learned from your coaching certification? 

The obvious answer would be, "How to coach people." Don't get me wrong, that skill set brings immeasurable value to my conversations and people I coach. 

The true answer is understanding that the greatest freedom in life is the freedom to choose. My eyes have been opened to how often we move through life in default mode, doing what comes our way or what we think we should do, not thinking of our actions are choices.

When in reality, EVERYTHING is a choice. An example: 

You get invited to a meeting. You read the invite. No agenda. Just from the title you have a sense that you don't need to be there. What's the choice? You can go because you were invited and so should go. You can ask for more details before you accept. You can assert yourself and say I don't believe I need to be in this meeting while staying open to learning more. 

But how many people stop to think through the best choice for themselves, the team, the client, etc? Most people will just go to the meeting, see what happens. Enough meetings like that can create resentment between team members, suck up time and impact real priorities. 

That is a small choice and practicing thinking through options and making a choice tied to a value or want in low-risk circumstances is key to building up your ability to make bigger value-driven choices in life. 

So what choices do you want to make today? 

Pictured: My favourite affirmation card that I made at a an amazing workshop at Studio Mooi (for Toronto folks, their workshops are must dos!). I keep it propped up at my desk.

I know I have some enablement and learning folks following me here so I want you to think honestly here. 

How many spreadsheets or dashboards do you have open right now trying to compile data? 

How many times have you been on the brink of an insight about team performance only to realize some discrepancy somewhere? 

Now, picture it. What if you could have one dashboard that out of the box displays data from across your tech stack? I'm talking Salesforce, Salesloft, Docebo, Gong, Outreach and more in one place. 

And what if it could also tell you how the sales training you just spent had to spend 6 months procuring, building a business case for and what feels like stake your reputation on is impacting business results? 

That's exactly what Richardson's Accelerate Insights is designed to do. Read more about the whole learning system at the link in the comments.

Once the voice in your head becomes more like a coach asking you what's possible and less like a gremlin telling you what's wrong with you, life really starts to change. 

It's taken me almost two years of practice and now I'm consistently seeing the world differently. I can see assumptions where I wouldn't have before and I am actively interested in understanding perspectives other than mine. 

Being coached was critical to kickstarting this pattern, but when I started consistently reflecting on my performance and how I show up in conversations, client interactions, and personal interactions, my own self-coaching became a force-multiplier. 

Even though there is always a next thing to move onto, take a few minutes at some point in the day or after important activities to reflect. 

Ask yourself: 
What did I learn from what happened today? 
How did I feel today? What led to that feeling? 
What would I do differently or all over again to get or prevent this feeling? 

Next: 
Tell yourself whatever happened and however you feel about it, the feeling is valid. It makes sense. Maybe expand on why you feel that way to yourself a bit to explore. 

Celebrate your wins and acknowledge your opportunities. 

Rinse, repeat, rinse, repeat. Eventually, you'll start to see things differently too. 

What's your self coaching routine?

This is an extremely niche post about formatting Word documents. I started my career in a role formatting documents, so formatting will always be a happy, calming activity for me. I also know a thing or two about how to fix any problem in Word or PowerPoint. 

Twice in the past few weeks I've shown someone the little hidden feature of Paragraph Spacing in Word and their minds are blown. It creates the ability to give word documents that extra little polish and gives more flexibility than pressing enter to make a space between paragraphs. 

Click through the photos below for my quick how-to. Play around with it and let me know if this is helpful!

It's my birthday! üéâI had a supercharged year of personal development and it's important to me to celebrate these wins. So here are my top three learnings I'm bringing into my next year of life with me. 

1. Learning my personal values, using them to make decisions and understanding when it serves me to honor one value vs. another made me happier. One of my top values is peace of mind. I can make decisions so easily with that in mind. Sometimes though I recognize I'll be happier if I go outside of my comfort zone and honor a different top value - growth. 

2.  I can hold two conflicting truths in my head at the same time and move forward. For example, no matter how much coaching I did around it, going to the networking event I went to recently was going to feel uncomfortable AND I knew I could go and make connections and enjoy myself. I didn't have to solve the uncomfortable, I accepted it and moved forward. 

3. I am not up against the clock. For as long as I can remember, time has given me anxiety. I had to be on time or early, then I've felt awkward about being places too early, but the fear of being late was too much. I have learned to let one thing flow into each other recognizing that even if I don't always have enough time, I can make it work or that it is simply okay to tell someone I'm running late. 

Thanks to anyone who's supported me in my growth in the last year!

You must shake the stigma of sales technology and stay up to speed on what's possible. 

This is some of Jake Dunlap's advice in his new book the Innovative Seller. I have to admit I was influenced by a few great posts about the book last week and thought I would pick it up. So far it's worth the read! 

As someone who has been talking to sales organizations about their challenges for a decade, one challenge that comes up a lot is that sellers don't effectively leverage their technology or that no one uses CRM effectively. I get how enablement teams get burnt out on acquiring new technology to solve a problem when the last one didn't stick. Status quo bias is real out there. 

What resonated with me most in the first few chapters is that we know technology is evolving faster than ever in ways that can massively help us and yet we let past failures hold us back. Two recommendations to reduce getting burned again: 

1. Focus on being more thoughtful in procurement about if a technology is really solving THE problem by involving the right stakeholders at the right time. 

2.  Understanding that the success of an implementation should be measured by how powerful the usage is across the org, not by speed to implementation. 

Jake offers helpful frameworks for accomplishing his two recommendations (among a ton more insight). Its made me think for sure. 

Has anyone else picked this up?

resharedPost.text:
Did you realize the words ‚Äòsilent‚Äô and ‚Äòlisten‚Äô have all of the same letters?

Listen and be silent. Or be silent and listen, if you prefer.

This is a key element from the concept of 'Hearing Offers'.

Let the silence linger an extra few questions and you‚Äôll be amazed at how much you will learn.

Yes, it‚Äôll feel uncomfortable, especially the first few times you do it. But with practice you‚Äôll learn to love it. I promise.

Check out our full post on Hearing Offers (and other persuasion tips from improv comedy) - link in the comments.
---------------
P.S. If you liked this, ‚ôªÔ∏è repost to share with your network too!
PPS: I didn't plan for my shirt to match the walls in this photo. But I'll go with it.

author.headline: Head of Programmatic Media at Google | Speaker | Board Director | Startup Advisor

data.text: A topic close to my heart, the power of silence. Had to share for the spelling fun fact as the hook!

A mindset shift that will help you feel more calm and confident is letting go of the need to be right. 
 
Until recently, being right about things was really important to me. I got huge satisfaction when something played out the way I thought it would. On the flipside, I felt extremely threatened when something I pushed for ended up being "wrong". I'd worry about what I should have done differently constantly. This worry trickled into the next conversation, project, etc. until I was always wondering what I could have done differently to be right. 

Enter the concept that things aren't right or wrong, they just are. Instead of focusing on being right, I chose a different lens to look at situations through. I chose "add value". I don't need to be right, but I do want to add value. 

Whether I am sharing an idea (which could go no where or spark a new direction to explore), choosing a restaurant for dinner (maybe we go there and it's wasn't that great, but hey, we ate!), or acknowledging a win (even though we didn't go the way I suggested), I don't need to be right. Instead, my goal is to make a contribution to the whole that adds value. 

I can't describe the impact of this mindset shift on my life other than saying it has set me free.

Have you ever considered how important is it to you to be right? What lens could you look at situations through instead? Think about it and if you want to chat about making this shift yourself, I'd love to talk about it!

Networking is not something I've ever had to do, but after four years of working remote, there has been a shift, it's something I want to do. 

One thing I was mindful of before my first networking event was making it easy for people to connect with me. Anyone else have a name that they can't stand to type or spell when you meet new people? The G and D in McGoldrick trip people up every time. Not anymore! 

Ahead of the event I attended last night organized by Rev Gen Inc. and Women in Sales, I made my own QR code phone wallpaper to make connecting easy. Turns out, LinkedIn has this function native to the app. So I have to share a how-to for this hidden but magic feature. 

In the LinkedIn app, tap the search bar, and in the far right of the bar there is a QR code icon. Tap the icon and you'll have your very own QR code image you can share, or download. Bonus points if you make it your phone wallpaper to make connecting easier than ever.

Do you want to be as accountable to your life goals as you are to your goals at work? 

Have you struggled with being accountable to your personal goals and feel guilty because you are used to being a high performer at work? Are you someone who always hits or exceeds milestones, and would never miss a meeting or a timeline at work?

But, when it comes to getting to the gym, completing a DIY home project, or starting a side hustle, you've missed milestones and promises made to yourself. 

I have felt this way myself, constantly letting myself down in my own life only to hustle M-F to accomplish everything I had to at work. 

Here's the thing - at work, we have a job description ‚Äì structure, responsibilities, metrics and time set aside to accomplish our goals. 

In life, we need to create that structure ourselves. 

If you struggle with this challenge, I invite you to start gaining clarity on how you want to live more successfully by creating a life description. 

Like a job description, but for your life! 

What‚Äôs your title? Just like the title of a book, you might want to do this last. 

What are the top 5 values you live by? 

What‚Äôs your mission statement? What do you want to accomplish, experience and create most in life?

What are your key accountabilities? Think about this from many lenses: yourself, family, friends, hobbies, a side hustle.

What are your key performance indicators? How will you know you‚Äôre being successful in your life? These can be both intangible and tangible. 

Now, it‚Äôs time for a performance review. How are you doing against your life description? What responsibilities are you executing on a regular basis? What needs more attention? What values are you living by? Which values need to be brought back to the forefront? Are your hitting your KPIs or is it time to refocus? 

When you find yourself falling short on your personal goals, go back to your life description and reflect on where you‚Äôre getting off your plan. 

How would creating a life description help you get back on track when you are falling short on your personal goals? 

Share this with someone who you want to help get back on track with their personal goals ‚úÖ

If you‚Äôve met me on video in the last year, you‚Äôve seen the art on the wall behind me. It‚Äôs a tapestry I made inspired by one of my favourite things in the world, the sky at sunset. 

Two years ago, I swore I‚Äôd never put anything on the wall behind me in my office because I was scared it would show too much of who I am. 

The secret to the shift I made is awareness of the value of knowing and sharing our gifts with the world. 

The connection I‚Äôve formed with people over my art has been so worth it. The story of that piece also highlights my strengths: patience to tie thousands of knots, problem solving because I designed it from scratch with no pattern and creativity to bring the vision to life. 

It is a representation of the unique skills, talents and thoughts I bring to every experience I‚Äôm a part of. 

This is a reminder that everyone has gifts and talents and the world is better knowing about them. What are your gifts and how can you share them?

A DIFFERENT TYPE OF AI 

I heard this concept on the Unlocking Us Podcast with Bren√© Brown and Esther Perel. Ester shared the concept of Artificial Intimacy. She defined Artificial Intimacy as, ‚ÄúThe experiences that we currently have that are pseudo-experiences. They should give us the feeling of something real but they don‚Äôt. I‚Äôm talking about something deeply personal, and the other person is answering with ‚Äúuh huh‚Äù or a thumbs up.‚Äù

This societal challenge is at the core of why I became a coach. 

We have learned to interact artificially, to be what‚Äôs expected of us, to be put together, to know exactly what we are doing, to be the most accomplished. The fear of being any other way holds us back from being who we are, both for ourselves and those around us. 

The impact of artificial intimacy often shows up in my coaching sessions. The biggest evidence to me is that people apologize a lot when they‚Äôre being coached. 

I‚Äôm sorry for rambling, I‚Äôm sorry my emotions are coming up, I‚Äôm sorry I don‚Äôt know why I brought that up. 

Most people aren‚Äôt comfortable being in a space to share honestly. A space to be heard. A space where it is all about them and all thoughts, feelings and actions are valid. 

When given that space and they recognize their real selves broke through, they feel the guilt, shame, and embarrassment that we have learned to feel through artificial interactions ‚Äì the times when we shared something to someone, and they weren‚Äôt really listening or made us feel what we shared was somehow wrong. 

In these moments, my role as a coach is to acknowledge and validate them. Soon after I‚Äôll usually say something like, you don‚Äôt have to apologize for being who you are. Thank you for sharing it with me.  

How would your day be different if more of your interactions were with people who were truly listening to you? For other coaches, how do you respond to people apologizing in coaching? 

It‚Äôs not lost on me that this post will receive mostly thumbs up reactions from people, it‚Äôs not easy to jump into the comments on a post like this and say ‚ÄúThanks for the post, I‚Äôm always apologizing for being who I am!‚Äù That‚Äôs okay, I appreciate the support either way. 

And if this post does make you think about the power of exploring who you are with someone invested in holding space for you, I‚Äôd love to start a conversation.

When I decided to jump in to posting more on LinkedIn, I honestly felt confident about it. I believe everyone has a story to tell. Reading what other people post made me feel like I could at least match their quality and learn as I go. After a few weeks of scrolling, I knew I had to go for it. Time to post and comment! 

Well ‚Äì in comes the limiting beliefs. The top two I‚Äôve dealt with so far‚Ä¶
1. I have nothing to post about.¬†
2. What can I add to this post when 30 people have already commented on it?

Staring at a blank page, when the ‚ÄúNew Posts‚Äù reminder keeps popping up proving to you just how many people have things to say, right now, doesn‚Äôt put the pressure on or anything¬†üôÉ. 

If you're dealing with these same limiting beliefs, here‚Äôs how I‚Äôve dealt with them so far: 
 
First, I write myself notes on Whatsapp all the time. Anytime I have a memorable conversation, experience or reaction, I note it down. Especially when listening to podcasts, I note the episode, and timestamp of the phrase that got me thinking. When I want to write a post, that‚Äôs the first place I go. 

Second, I turned on notifications for some of my favourite LinkedIn personalities, so I am notified when they post. That way it‚Äôs easier for me to jump into the discussion before the comment count gets too high. I‚Äôve also started to go into the comments to see what the discussion is like even if the number is high. Lots of people double their comment counts quickly by responding to everyone immediately. It‚Äôs worth clicking through to check! 

Anytime you put yourself out there, it is intimidating. Don't let the feeling of being intimidated stop you. Even if you aren‚Äôt as successful as others, posting a few times a week or month is more than most people are doing. So by that metric, you‚Äôre already successful.

End of Q1 Personal Goal Check-in: 3 months since I deleted TikTok

At the end of 2023 I realized I was addicted to TikTok. 

I would open the app while microwaving food for 30 seconds, while I made my coffee, for 30 minutes every morning before I got out of bed, and before I went to sleep. Everyday when I finished work, I‚Äôd go on the app for a solid 45 minutes to an hour. I‚Äôd charge my phone multiple times a day to accommodate the screentime. 

I felt gross about how much time I was spending on TikTok. 

So on New Year‚Äôs Eve, I deleted TikTok. The next few days were a rude awakening as I realized how many times I went to open the app only to not have an app to open. I made myself wait for my food in the microwave without my phone in hand and listen to the sounds the coffee machine made. Now, I always need to have a book nearby (I‚Äôm on my 10th of the year). I started going to the gym before work so I couldn‚Äôt start my day on my phone. 

Now, I can‚Äôt say I don‚Äôt miss TikTok, I still have an unshakeable craving to zone out on TikTok after a busy work day. If I ever download the app again, I will have to find a way to limit my time and attention to it. 
¬†
Apps can easily become such a big part of our lives. Everyone knows apps are designed to be addictive. Some people might have this kind of relationship with their email app. If you find yourself opening an app every moment your hands are free, or leaving your food to get cold in the microwave because you were distracted by it, it might be time to take a break or at least set some healthy boundaries.  

What personal goals have you been working on in 2024?

ARE YOU THINKING OF MAKING A CHANGE? 


Whether it is big or small, many people stumble through making change happen successfully. People are prone to jumping right into action, and then when they fail or make a mistake, they get totally discouraged and feel stuck. Thoughts might come up like, "I can't do it." or "This wasn't the right path for me anyways."  

To increase your chance of being successful in making a change, don't skip the SHUFFLE phase. 

Think about it. When playing cards and the dealer is shuffling, you're excited right? All possibilities are up in the air. You might be rethinking your strategy from last round or getting focused for the next round. You don't have to do anything while the cards are being shuffled except think about what you want to do in the next round. 

When it comes to change, before diving into action, take time to imagine all possibilities, come to terms with past choices and get excited about you want to do next. 

How does this idea of the Shuffle Phase in Change resonate with you? 
________________________________________

The concept of the Cycle of Change is one of the incredible frameworks I learned from my iPEC coaching program.

My 10th book of the year and first non-fiction read üìö



I‚Äôm really excited to dive in to expand my thinking on topic. The cover and tagline immediately jumped out at me at the store because it captures the type of impact I want to create through coaching. I want to help individuals connect to who they are and learn to live by their own values instead of responding to how the world tells us we should be.

CONFESSIONS OF A CANADIAN BUILDING RAPPORT WITH AMERICANS 


Working remote with a majority US-based team and client base, I realized today that not knowing what the temperature is in Fahrenheit is impacting my ability to build rapport with them. 

We all want to build great, personalized rapport, and let's be honest, we all talk about the weather at least once a day. Especially with the unusual winter we've had, it comes up a lot. 

Today, I was on a client call and everyone was talking about the temperature where they are. I felt myself hoping no one would ask me what the temperature is where I'm based. I totally shrunk in that moment and then it takes me time to find myself again and engage. 

When I am asked, I usually jump into my canned response, "oh well I'm in Canada so I don't know Fahrenheit exactly but best guess is this number." It doesn't feel like me to be so uncomfortable in such a frequent mundane conversation. In these moments I want to connect with people, not be caught up in differences between us. 

Today I'm finally taking action and making myself a Fahrenheit to Celsius cheat sheet. It's going on my desktop so I won't have to think about this again. This might sound obvious, or like something I could have googled months ago and that is true. However, it was only in the moment when I recognized my discomfort in the situation that I was motivated enough to solve this problem forever. 

What holds you back from fully engaging in rapport building?

resharedPost.text:
Daylight saving time begins this weekend here in the U.S., which means we'll be ‚Äòspringing forward‚Äô  an hour. ‚è∞

While some might be looking forward to longer days and more sun, others might feel frustrated, anxious, or maybe just tired from losing an hour of sleep. ü•± And all of these feelings are valid!

Let‚Äôs look at some different ways we might experience this time shift, through the lens of the 7 Levels of Energy.

(Pssst! If you‚Äôre enrolled in Mod I this weekend in a US-based timezone, or you‚Äôre an iPEC grad who‚Äôs enrolled in a live training this month, don‚Äôt forget to plan accordingly!)

data.text:
Ahh Daylight Savings Time, one of those things in life you have no control over. It just happens to you, so it‚Äôs easy to resent it. I‚Äôd guess lots of people have a Level 2 reaction, I know I do. Reflecting on these perspectives, I can take a Level 4 approach to it. I‚Äôm barely impacted, why harbour a negative reaction to it? 

It‚Äôs powerful to consider your reaction to the things you can‚Äôt control.

How can you measure personal growth?


STORY TIME:  

I had a very frustrating travel experience on Thursday (8 hours at the airport, put on standby, put on a flight to a different city so I could arrive before my vacation was supposed to be over üôÉ).

Although I‚Äôd never outwardly show it, in the past if this happened, in my head I‚Äôd be fuming. Why me? How could this happen? I‚Äôll never get there! I hate airports! 

This time because I‚Äôve been working on my awareness of my thoughts, feelings and actions, I was aware of how I felt. Frustrated by the change in plans, scared my flight would be canceled, and bored of the airport. Once I took stock of all that, I felt better. The situation wasn‚Äôt great and I wanted to be with my family having fun! It made sense to be frustrated, scared and bored. 

Acknowledging my feelings helped me tune into how much I wanted to get there vs. being stuck on why did this happen to me? My core focus became just getting to the destination. 

Later, when I was told I was no longer on my flight and I had one option to fly into a different airport on a flight leaving in 30 mins, I jumped at the chance knowing I had the means to make the longer journey on arrival. I didn‚Äôt doubt my decision for one second. As someone who frequently overthinks before making decisions, this is big for me. 

Once I was on the plane I was filled with gratefulness that I was on my way, everything that just happened truly didn‚Äôt matter anymore. No blame, no doubt. 

So how can you measure personal growth? 

To me, it‚Äôs how often are you achieving what you want to and how do you feel when you do? 

*pictured - me on the plane happy to be on my way

I've had a day that was book-ended by the topic of presence. 

Mim (Miriam) Abbey had a great post this morning that zoomed into executive presence. I shared a comment there about a mindset I've been focused on. Instead of being stuck in the mindset of "Am I bringing enough value to this meeting?", my mindset has been "be in the moment in the meeting, tuned in and staying present to add value."

Then, tonight in a coaching peer group meeting with Paul R. Haut, Milly Kabas and Ruth McGee, we talked about what it means to bring presence to your coaching sessions. It was an impactful discussion. I appreciate so much learning from this group and their unique perspectives and experiences. 

Now I'm off to be present on the beach for a few days with family!

Has anyone ever told you to ‚Äújust let it be‚Äù?

I was talking to a friend this weekend about letting go of things they can‚Äôt control and they asked me for my advice. My advice usually comes in the form of a question, so I asked them ‚ÄúWhat would you say if I told you that instead of trying to control an outcome, you can let the situation be?‚Äù

Turns out, they‚Äôve heard that before, they‚Äôve been ‚Äúworking on it‚Äù and it led to a point of frustration. They asked me, ‚ÄúHow do I just let it be when everything inside me is telling me to fix it?‚Äù 

Letting it be is a road paved by intentional action. We aren‚Äôt all mindful enough (yet) that letting it be is a single action. 

We ended up identifying the thought and feelings that come up when they want to fix something. 

And we stopped there! Working on awareness about what set them into fix-it mode was an actionable step they felt they could take on. The rest of the road to ‚Äúletting it be‚Äù will be paved in time. Another thing, everyone‚Äôs actions will look different. There is no one-size-fits-all path to letting go of what you want to control. 

What is your reaction to being told to ‚Äújust let it be‚Äù? 

If you want support breaking down what intentional action on that path looks like for you, I am open to chat!

resharedPost.text:
If setting boundaries feels challenging, rest assured you‚Äôre not alone! While naming your boundary or saying no can be stressful (which is totally normal!), it's a crucial skill for protecting your inner peace.

Let's explore what the process of setting boundaries might look like, from the inside out.

data.text:
As a process-oriented person, I love seeing a topic as challenging as setting boundaries broken down into practical steps. 

If there are boundaries you'd like to set and could use support in each of the steps below, I'm equipped to guide you through it. Send me a DM or reach me at coaching@kimmcgoldrick.com. 

React below if this process will help you!

I‚Äôm noticing any interesting day after Valentine‚Äôs Day trend here on LinkedIn‚Ä¶

Almost every post on my feed has started with ‚ÄúToday, I want to share something that has been on my heart lately.‚Äù 

Is this the subliminal influence of seeing so many hearts yesterday? 

Or did Valentine‚Äôs Day give people a chance to feel their emotions and connect to something or someone important to them? 

I can tell you that I vote for the second option. Yesterday, I felt pieces of my life fall into place that I‚Äôve been working on over the last few months and the holiday gave me a chance to reflect on that. 

What do you think? And if you‚Äôre with me, what‚Äôs on your heart you want to share? Tell me below!

poll.title: What is the cause of many ‚Äúsharing something on my heart‚Äù posts on LinkedIn the day after Valentine‚Äôs Day?

data.text:
On the recommendation of Molly M., I‚Äôve been listening to the audiobook ‚ÄúNever Not Working‚Äù. While I don‚Äôt consider myself a workaholic, I‚Äôm interested in understanding the beliefs and expectations that cause people to overwork. 

My biggest challenge about listening to the book is that the message is so clear that listening while doing anything else - cooking, cleaning, any of my usual audiobook/podcast split focus tasks - immediately feels like doing too much. 

I have considered that I could stop listening. Then my thoughts start going, ‚ÄúNo you have to finish this, it‚Äôs good for your book count for the year.‚Äù ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt listen, you‚Äôre missing out on key info that might help you or a client.‚Äù I decided I will listen only when I‚Äôm commuting so I can focus on the content. Even that is technically doing two things at once üôÉ. 

It‚Äôs really that easy to stop listening to what your body is telling you and power through. When you‚Äôre powering through all the time for work or other priorities that are on your mind all the time it‚Äôs no wonder so many people are on a fast track to burnout. 

My message here is to be present, but more pointedly, find things you can do simply for the joy of doing them. 

When is the last time you did one singular thing, just because it brought you joy, with no metrics attached to it?

resharedPost.text:
Consciously choosing to cultivate kindness in our thoughts, words, and actions can sow the seeds of positive change, both within ourselves and in the world around us. üå±

To learn more about the energy of compassion‚Äîwhich we call Level 4 Energy!‚Äîvisit our blog: https://bit.ly/4bkepjs

data.text:
In my career, I've been given feedback that I need to bring more empathy to my interactions. 

At the time, I didn't understand. It felt like being told I was a mean person, when at my core I knew that I would do whatever it took to help my team be successful. 

Fast forward to now, I've learned a lot about how to translate my intention of empathy and support into my words and actions. It's a daily conscious choice for me to bring kindness and compassion to all my interactions. 

Guess what? 

Now I've received feedback that people feel a more compassionate energy from me! ‚ú® 

Tell me below, what's one small way you can bring compassion, kindness or empathy to a new part of your life? 

DM me if you'd like to chat 1:1 about it!
